prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Relationship to other forms of transfer and consolidation—Comparison to venue

para.paratext: Transfer by the Panel for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is similar to venue in appearance, but there are important differences. As discussed earlier, the Panel's power to transfer is both broader and more narrowly defined than that under venue statutes.[1] Venue and multidistrict transfer are related, however, for both seek to advance the convenience of the parties and witnesses.[2]

The transfer decision under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 is generally recognized to be different from the transfer decision under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a), the venue statute that allows transfer for the convenience of witnesses and parties.[3] The standards for transfer are different under the two statutes, and the Panel has recognized that a decision relating to transfer under § 1404(a) does not dictate its decision regarding transfer under § 1407.[4] The Panel has, however, also recognized that the two standards include consideration of certain related or common factors and that a decision under one standard may be the same as under another.[5]

The most significant difference between §§ 1404(a) and 1407 transfer is the power of the Panel in a single proceeding before it under § 1407 to order transfer of all related actions to a single district. To effect transfer of multiple actions under § 1404(a) separate motions must be brought in each action. That process is time-consuming and expensive, and creates the risk that the motions would not be given the same treatment in the individual courts.

The fact that transfer under § 1407 is only for pretrial proceedings also distinguishes it from true change of venue under § 1404(a). Especially after the United States Supreme Court decision in Lexecon,[6] the Panel has recognized that the broader scope of a 1404(a) motion may justify its declining to entertain a 1407 transfer motion.[7] Where there are a large number of actions pending, however, this alternative will not likely be appealing to the Panel.[8] In some cases transfer would be appropriate for pretrial proceedings but not for trial; in other cases transfer of some cases for trial would be appropriate although consolidated pretrial proceedings would offer little efficiency. This difference results in a real difference in the decision to be made by the judge or panel considering transfer. Many judges are reluctant to consider motions for change of venue under § 1404(a) for the convenience of witnesses until discovery is essentially completed and the probable witnesses can be identified.[9] Transfer by the Panel only requires consideration of the location and nature of the pretrial proceedings, while change of venue requires considerations primarily of trial. These concerns may be diametrically different.

Transfer or change of venue may present a difficult or even impossible choice for the court because of the necessity that the transferee forum be one in which the action could have been initially brought.[10] If there are multiple parties, dismissal or retention of some claims and transfer of the others to a district where the defendants could be sued may be necessitated.[11] Transfer by the Panel permits all cases to be transferred to a single district without regard to venue concerns. This may make the transfer decision more palatable to the judge since it does not require carving up the litigation.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
